Award.AwardTitle: US-UK Collab: Risks of Animal and Plant Infectious Diseases through Trade (RAPID Trade)
Award.AbstractNarration:
World trade is a boon to economic development but it also increases the risk of dispersing human, animal, and plant diseases. Disease impacts on crop yields and livestock put global food supplies at risk and newly emergent diseases that move from animals to humans can threaten human health. But because trade is also one of the main drivers of economic development, it is important that it not be disrupted unnecessarily by measures to protect against disease risk. Striking the right balance is currently difficult to achieve, however, because trade impacts are not systematically incorporated into national and international disease risk assessments. This award supports an interdisciplinary and international team who seek to solve that problem by developing new tools for evaluating the disease risks of world trade. The risk assessment tools produced by the project will provide animal, plant, and human health authorities at national and international levels with the capacity to make improved assessment of the disease risks associated with imports, and of the consequences of alternative trade responses. Improving disease risk management will enhance national security and economic well-being by reducing both disease dispersal and the losses caused by trade interdictions. The project also will strengthen collaborations between US and UK scientists and train graduate students and post-doctoral scientists in research.

The researchers will compile data from multiple secondary sources. Data on plant diseases, livestock and wildlife diseases, disease outbreaks, and global emerging diseases, will be provided by such sources as the National Plant Protection Organizations in the United States and the United Kingdom, the United States Department of Agriculture's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, and the UK Food and Environment Research Agency. Public domain databases will provide time series data on trade, including trade volumes, trade values, sanitary and phtyosanitary conditions along trade pathways in exporting and importing countries, as well as Gross Domestic Product (GDP) data to estimate national value at risk. These data will be used to parameterize econometric profit maximization risk models to assess the effects of trader decisions and trade networks on the transmission of disease. The models will consider the intervention in trade at three spatial scales (local, national, and global) on incidence of disease transport and effects of altered trade on economic development. The models will be incorporated into a virtual laboratory decision support system to help evaluate alternative incentive-based trade management practices and the effects of decisions on the risk of disease spread.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project goals.  The COVID-19 pandemic is a sharp reminder that emerging infectious diseases are spread internationally through trade and travel.  One of the earliest responses to the outbreak in the USA was a limited ban on trade and travel from China. The RAPID Trade project was initiated to deepen understanding of the effect of trade and travel on the transmission of a range of infectious diseases of humans, animals and plants.  Project scientists were drawn from universities in both the US (Arizona State University, University of Alaska, University of California Davis, Georgia State University, Michigan State University, Princeton University, Yale University, University of Wyoming) and the UK (University of York, Stirling University), as well as the EcoHealth Alliance. Through partnerships with the US Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (US APHIS) and UK Food and Environment research Agency (UK FERA), they undertook studies designed to improve understanding of the disease risks of trade and travel, to develop trade-risk assessment methods in support of local and national disease risk management, to improve capacity to predict the implications of trade interventions for the wider risk landscape, and to explore options for managing the disease risks of trade and travel at the international scale. 

 

Project outputs.  Major outputs include: (a) risk-based inspection models to improve the interception of plant diseases at the border, (b) predictive disease transmission models that show how economic factors affect transmission rates, (c) enhanced models for the management of infectious diseases affecting wild and domesticated animals of different species, and (d) proposals for the creation of a global pandemic fund to fight large scale emergence events. An extension of the project considered how peoples’ movements in response to natural disasters—specifically hurricanes—affect the disease risks posed by such events.  In the final eight months of the project the focus moved to COVID-19. Research covered the role of Wuhan ‘wet markets’ in transmission of the disease, the impact of mobility restrictions on transmission rates, and factors affecting differences in case fatality ratios in more and less developed countries. 

 

Project findings.  An overarching finding of the project is that the transmission of infectious diseases depends on the way people manage the risks of market activities. Infectious disease is one of the risks associated with trade and travel.  People balance the risk to themselves against the potential gains to be had, but without taking account of the risks to others.  The greater the private gains from trade, the greater the private disease-risk people are willing to take, and the more resources they are willing to commit to biosecurity measures designed to mitigate risk. Moreover, this holds for infectious diseases of humans, animals, and plants alike. One implications of this finding is that predictive models that include the range of factors affecting trade and travel decisions perform better than models that do not. A second is that in addition to the conventional public health and biosecurity measures used to manage infectious disease risks, governments can use economic instruments (taxes, charges, financial penalties, or subsidies) to mitigate the risk to society by altering trade and travel decisions. 

 

At the international level, infectious disease management requires coordination and cooperation between national governments through both intergovernmental bodies such as the World Health Organization (WHO), the World Organization for Animal Health (OIE), the World Trade Organization (WTO) and a range of bilateral and multilateral treaties. The resources to mitigate pandemic risk available through these organizations is, however, inadequate.  Following the 2014 West African Ebola Virus outbreak, project scientists proposed the establishment of a global pandemic fund to serve as global insurance against the threat of emerging infectious diseases, to strengthen mobile and adaptable capacity to deal with disease emergence, and to provide access to safe treatment during and between outbreaks in developing countries. They found that establishment and maintenance of a fund aimed both at mitigating the risk of outbreaks, and enhancing capacity to deal with outbreaks that do occur, would generate significant net-benefits to developed and developing countries alike.
